Neuralgia of the sciatic nerve, an affection characterized by paroxysmal attacks of pain in the buttock, back of the thing, or in the leg or foot, following the course of the branches of the sciatic nerve. The name is also popularly applied to various painful affections of the hip and the parts adjoininhg. See Ischiadic passion, under Ischiadic.
With, or by means of, sciatica.
Knowledge; lnowledge of principles and causes; ascertained truth of facts.
Agreeing with, or depending on, the rules or principles of science; as, a scientific classification; a scientific arrangement of fossils.
A glucoside extracted from squill (Scilla) as a light porous substance.
A bitter principle extracted from the bulbs of the squill (Scilla), and probably consisting of a complex mixture of several substances.
A saber with a much curved blade having the edge on the convex side, -- in use among Mohammedans, esp., the Arabs and persians.
A long-handled billhook. See Billhook.
A tribe of lizards including the skinks. See Skink.

Any one of numerous species of lizards of the family Scincid\'91 or tribe Scincoidea. The tongue is not extensile. The body and tail are covered with overlapping scales, and the toes are margined. See Illust. under Skink.
Some kind of stinging or biting insect, as a flea, a gnat, a sandly, or the like.
A spark; the least particle; an iota; a tittle.
To sparkle, as the fixed stars.
A spark of flash emitted in scintillating.
In a scintillant manner.
The knowledge of a sciolist; superficial knowledge.
One who knows many things superficially; a pretender to science; a smatterer.
Knowing superficially or imperfectly.
A shoot or sprout of a plant; a sucker.
Hence, a descendant; an heir; as, a scion of a royal stock.
The art or process of exhibiting luminous images, especially those of external objects, in a darkened room, by arrangements of lenses or mirrors.
Of or pertaining to the island Scio (Chio or Chios).
Of or pertaining to a sundial.
Proceeding from scirrhus; of the nature of scirrhus; indurated; knotty; as, scirrhous affections; scirrhous disease.
An indurated organ or part; especially, an indurated gland.
The act of inquiring; inquiry; demand.
The slips or plates of metal out of which circular balnks have been cut for the purpose of coinage.
Capable of being cut smoothly; scissible.
To cut with scissors or shears; to prepare with the aid of scissors.

A tyrant flycatcher (Milvulus forficatus) of the Southern United States and Mexico, which has a deeply forked tail. It is light gray above, white beneath, salmon on the flanks, and fiery red at the base of the crown feathers.
Having the outer feathers much the longest, the others decreasing regularly to the median ones.
A longitudinal opening in a body, made by cutting; a cleft; a fissure.
Of or pertaining to the Squirrel family.
Resembling the tail of a squirrel; -- generally said of branches which are close and dense, or of spikes of grass like barley.
A tribe of rodents containing the squirrels and allied animals, such as the gophers, woodchucks, beavers, and others.
A genus of reodents comprising the common squirrels.
A morbid induration of the edge of the eyelid.
A hard chitinous or calcareous process or corpuscle, especially a spicule of the Alcyonaria.
The calcareous or hornlike coral forming the central stem or axis of most compound alcyonarians; -- called also foot secretion. See Illust. under Gorgoniacea, and C\'d2nenchyma.
One of a tribe of plectognath fishes (Sclerodermi) having the skin covered with hard scales, or plates, as the cowfish and the trunkfish.
A disease of adults, characterized by a diffuse rigidity and hardness of the skin.
The stony corals; the Madreporaria.
Having the integument, or skin, hard, or covered with hard plates.
The hard integument of Crustacea.
The thickening matter of woody cells; lignin.
Making or secreting a hard substance; becoming hard.
Having a hard texture, as nutshells.
Induration of the tissues. See Sclerma, Scleroderma, and Sclerosis.
An instrument for determining with accuracy the degree of hardness of a mineral.
Induration; hardening; especially, that form of induration produced in an organ by increase of its interstitial connective tissue.
Hardening of the cell wall by lignification.
Of or pertaining to the sclerotic coat of the eye; sclerotical.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from ergot or the sclerotium of a fungus growing on rye.
Inflammation of the sclerotic coat.
A hardened body formed by certain fungi, as by the Claviceps purpurea, which produced ergot.
The nature or resting stage of a plasmodium.
To prop; to scotch.
Having the form of, or resembling, sawdust or raspings.
Raspings of ivory, hartshorn, metals, or other hard substance.
The dross of metals.
An object of scorn, mockery, or derision.
To find fault or rail with rude clamor; to brawl; to utter harsh, rude, boisterous rebuke; to chide sharply or coarsely; -- often with at; as, to scold at a servant.
One who scolds, or makes a practice of scolding; esp., a rude, clamorous woman; a shrew.
A scolding; a brawl.
The oyster catcher; -- so called from its shrill cries.
A zeolitic mineral occuring in delicate radiating groups of white crystals. It is a hydrous silicate of aluminia and lime. Called also lime mesotype.
The embryo produced directly from the egg in a metagenetic series, especially the larva of a tapeworm or other parasitic worm. See Illust. of Echinococcus.
To go to school; to study.
A tubular structure found in Potsdam sandstone, and believed to be the fossil burrow of a marine worm.
Of or pertaining to the Scolopacid\'91, or Snipe family.
A genus of venomous myriapods including the centipeds. See Centiped.
Any one of numerous species of small bark-boring beetles of the genus Scolytus and allied genera. Also used adjectively.
A genus of acanthopterygious fishes which includes the common mackerel.
Like or pertaining to the Mackerel family.
To suffocate or stifle; to smother.
A flout; a jeer; a gibe; a taunt.
A hut for protection and shelter; a stall.
To mulct; to fine.
A cake, thinner than a bannock, made of wheat or barley or oat meal.
A deep shovel, or any similar implement for digging out and dipping or shoveling up anything; as, a flour scoop; the scoop of a dredging machine.
To empty by lading; as, to scoop a well dry.
The avocet; -- so called because it scoops up the mud to obtain food.
A yellow gelatinous or crystalline substance found in broom (Cytisus scoparius) accompanying sparte\'8bne.
Having the surface closely covered with hairs, like a brush.
A combining form usually signifying an instrument for viewing (with the eye) or observing (in any way); as in microscope, telescope, altoscope, anemoscope.
Like or pertaining to fishes of the genus Scopelus, or family Scopelod\'91, which includes many small oceanic fishes, most of which are phosphorescent.
Bearing a tuft of brushlike hairs.
Having the form of a broom or besom.
To lade or dip out.
Any species of bee which has on the hind legs a brush of hairs used for collecting pollen, as the hive bees and bumblebees.
Full of rocks; rocky.
Barter. [Obs.] See Scorse.
To burn superficially; to parch, or shrivel, the surface of, by heat; to subject to so much heat as changes color and texture without consuming; as, to scorch linen.
To burn or be burnt.
A notch or incision; especially, one that is made as a tally mark; hence, a mark, or line, made for the purpose of account.
An account or reckoning; account of dues; bill; hence, indebtedness.
The recrement of metals in fusion, or the slag rejected after the eduction of metallic ores; dross.
Cellular slaggy lava; volcanic cinders.
The young of any gull.
The act, process, or result of scorifying, or reducing to a slag; hence, the separation from earthy matter by means of a slag; as, the scorification of ores.

One who, or that which, scorifies; specifically, a small flat bowl-shaped cup used in the first heating in assaying, to remove the earth and gangue, and to concentrate the gold and silver in a lead button.
In the form of scoria.

To reduce to scoria or slag; specifically, in assaying, to fuse so as to separate the gangue and earthy material, with borax, lead, soda, etc., thus leaving the gold and silver in a lead button; hence, to separate from, or by means of, a slag.
A leek-green or brownish mineral occurring in orthorhombic crystals. It is a hydrous arseniate of iron.

Of or pertaining to the family Scorp\'91nid\'91, which includes the scorpene, the rosefish, the California rockfishes, and many other food fishes. [Written also scorp\'91nid.] See Illust. under Rockfish.
A marine food fish of the genus Scorp\'91na, as the European hogfish (S. scrofa), and the California species (S. guttata).
The eighth sign of the zodiac, which the sun enters about the twenty-third day of October, marked thus [&scorpio;] in almanacs.
Having the inflorescence curved or circinate at the end, like a scorpion's tail.
Any one of numerous species of pulmonate arachnids of the order scorpiones, having a suctorial mouth, large claw-bearing palpi, and a caudal sting.
The pine or gray lizard (Sceloporus undulatus).
A leguminous plant (Ornithopus scorpides) of Southern Europe, having curved pods.
A name for a horse.
A portion of money assessed or paid; a tax or contribution; a mulct; a fine; a shot.
Of or pertaining to Scotland, its language, or its inhabitants; Scottish.
Collectively, the people of Scotland.
A chock, wedge, prop, or other support, to prevent slipping; as, a scotch for a wheel or a log on inclined ground.
To cut superficially; to wound; to score.
Dressing stone with a pick or pointed instrument.
A native or inhabitant of Scotland; a Scot; a Scotsman.
A piece of wood or stiff hide placed over shrouds and other rigging to prevent chafe by the running gear.
A concave molding used especially in classical architecture.
An instrument for writing in the dark, or without seeing.
Dizziness with dimness of sight.
Obscuration of the field of vision due to the appearance of a dark spot before the eye.
The burning of a wad of pease straw at the end of harvest.
An idiom, or mode of expression, peculiar to Scotland or Scotchmen.
Of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Scotland, their country, or their language; as, Scottish industry or economy; a Scottish chief; a Scottish dialect.
A mean, worthless fellow; a rascal; a villain; a man without honor or virtue.
The domain or sphere of scoundrels; scoundrels, collectively; the state, ideas, or practices of scoundrels.
To purge; as, to scour a horse.
Refuse water after scouring.
One who, or that which, scours.
A rover or footpad; a prowling robber.
To punish with severity; to chastise; to afflict, as for sins or faults, and with the purpose of correction.
A sailor's dish. Bread scouse contains no meat; lobscouse contains meat, etc. See Lobscouse.
A large flat-bottomed boat, having broad, square ends.
To transport in a scow.
To wrinkle the brows, as in frowning or displeasure; to put on a frowning look; to look sour, sullen, severe, or angry.
Hence, to look gloomy, dark, or threatening; to lower.
To express by a scowl; as, to scowl defiance.
Hence, gloom; dark or threatening aspect.
A Lenten dish, composed of eggs boiled hard, chopped, and seasoned with butter, salt, and pepper.
To make irregular, crooked, or unmeaning marks; to scribble; to scrawl.
The act of scrabbing; a moving upon the hands and knees; a scramble; also, a scribble.
To scramble or struggle; to wrangle; also, to be industrious.
Lean and rough; scraggy.
in a scraggy manner.
The quality or state of being scraggy; scraggedness.
Rough with irregular points; scragged.
Lean and rough; scragged.
Having a scraggy neck.
To clamber with hands and knees; to scrabble; as, to scramble up a cliff; to scramble over the rocks.
To struggle eagerly with others for something thrown upon the ground; to go down upon all fours to seize something; to catch rudely at what is desired.
To prepare (eggs) as a dish for the table, by stirring the yolks and whites together while cooking.
The act of jostling and pushing for something desired; eager and unceremonious struggle for what is thrown or held out; as, a scramble for office.
A greedy and unceremonious contestant.
Slight; thin; lean; poor. Having
Something scraped off; hence, a small piece; a bit; a fragment; a detached, incomplete portion.
Specifically, a fragment of something written or printed; a brief excerpt; an unconnected extract.

To rub over the surface of (something) with a sharp or rough instrument; to rub over with something that roughens by removing portions of the surface; to grate harshly over; to abrade; to make even, or bring to a required condition or form, by moving the sharp edge of an instrument breadthwise over the surface with pressure, cutting away excesses and superfluous parts; to make smooth or clean; as, to scrape a bone with a knife; to scrape a metal plate to an even surface.
To remove by rubbing or scraping (in the sense above).
To occupy one's self with getting laboriously; as, he scraped and saved until he became rich.
A drawing back of the right foot when bowing; also, a bow made with that accompaniment.
An instrument with which anything is scraped.
Something scraped off; that which is separated from a substance, or is collected by scraping; as, the scraping of the street.
In a scrappy manner; in scraps.
To score, not by skillful play but by some fortunate chance of the game.
A stiff wire brush for cleaning iron castings and other metal.
The first coat in plastering; -- called also scratchwork. See Pricking-up.
One who, or that which, scratches; specifically (Zo\'94l.), any rasorial bird.
With the action of scratching.
Meager; thin; rawboned; bony; scranny.
A tern; the sea swallow.
Capable of being spit out.
A creaking; a screech; a shriek.
Having the nature of a scream; like a scream; shrill; sharp.
Like a screech; shrill and harsh.
A strip of plaster of the thickness proposed for the coat, applied to the wall at intervals of four or five feet, as a guide.
A fragment; a portion; a shred.
An harangue; a long tirade on any subject.
To pass, as coal, gravel, ashes, etc., through a screen in order to separate the coarse from the fine, or the worthless from the valuable; to sift.

A cylinder, or a cylindrical perforation, having a continuous rib, called the thread, winding round it spirally at a constant inclination, so as to leave a continuous spiral groove, between one turn and the next, -- used chiefly for producing, when revolved, motion or pressure in the direction of its axis, by the sliding of the threads of the cylinder in the grooves between the threads of the perforation adapted to it, the former being distinguished as the external, or male screw, or, more usually the screw; the latter as the internal, or female screw, or, more usually, the nut.

Specifically, a kind of nail with a spiral thread and a head with a nick to receive the end of the screw-driver. Screws are much used to hold together pieces of wood or to fasten something; -- called also wood screws, and screw nails. See also Screw bolt, below.
To force; to squeeze; to press, as by screws.
To turn one's self uneasily with a twisting motion; as, he screws about in his chair.
A tool for turning screws so as to drive them into their place. It has a thin end which enters the nick in the head of the screw.
One who, or that which, screws.
a. & n. from Screw, v. t.
Skillful in, or fond of, writing.
To card coarsely; to run through the scribling machine.
To write hastily or carelessly, without regard to correctness or elegance; as, to scribble a letter.
To fill or cover with careless or worthless writing.
The act or process of carding coarsely.
In a scribbling manner.
One who writes; a draughtsman; a writer for another; especially, an offical or public writer; an amanuensis or secretary; a notary; a copyist.
A writer and doctor of the law; one skilled in the law and traditions; one who read and explained the law to the people.

To cut (anything) in such a way as to fit closely to a somewhat irregular surface, as a baseboard to a floor which is out of level, a board to the curves of a molding, or the like; -- so called because the workman marks, or scribe, with the compasses the line that he afterwards cuts.
The character and opinions of a Jewish scribe in the time of Christ.
A kind of light cotton or linen fabric, often woven in openwork patterns, -- used for curtains, etc,; -- called also India scrim.
Thin canvas glued on the inside of panels to prevent shrinking, checking, etc.
The struggle in the rush lines after the ball is put in play.
A pinching miser; a niggard.
a. & n. from Scrimp, v. t.
The state of being scrimp.
A small portion; a pittance; a little bit.
A shell, a whale's tooth, or the like, that is scrimshawed.
A chest, bookcase, or other place, where writings or curiosities are deposited; a shrine.
A small bag; a wallet; a satchel.
Type made in imitation of handwriting.
The quality or state of being scriptural; literal adherence to the Scriptures.
One who adheres literally to the Scriptures.
In a scriptural manner.
Quality of being scriptural.
Anything written; a writing; a document; an inscription.
One who is strongly attached to, or versed in, the Scriptures, or who endeavors to regulate his life by them.
Pertaining to, or surrounding, scrobicul\'91; as, scrobicular tubercles.
Having numerous small, shallow depressions or hollows; pitted.
A young codfish, especially when cut open on the back and dressed.
Mottled pottery made from scraps of differently colored clays.

A constitutional disease, generally hereditary, especially manifested by chronic enlargement and cheesy degeneration of the lymphatic glands, particularly those of the neck, and marked by a tendency to the development of chronic intractable inflammations of the skin, mucous membrane, bones, joints, and other parts, and by a diminution in the power of resistance to disease or injury and the capacity for recovery. Scrofula is now generally held to be tuberculous in character, and may develop into general or local tuberculosis (consumption).
Any affection of the skin dependent on scrofula.
Pertaining to scrofula, or partaking of its nature; as, scrofulous tumors; a scrofulous habit of body.
Diseased or affected with scrofula.
Abounding in scrog; also, twisted; stunted.
A genus of coarse herbs having small flowers in panicled cymes; figwort.

Of or pertaining to a very large natural order of gamopetalous plants (Scrophulariace\'91, or Scrophularine\'91), usually having irregular didynamous flowers and a two-celled pod. The order includes the mullein, foxglove, snapdragon, figwort, painted cup, yellow rattle, and some exotic trees, as the Paulownia.
Of or pertaining to the scrotum; as, scrotal hernia.
A rupture or hernia in the scrotum; scrotal hernia.
The bag or pouch which contains the testicles; the cod.
To crowd; to squeeze.
A clipping from skins; a currier's cuttings.
To rub anything hard, especially with a wet brush; to scour; hence, to be diligent and penurious; as, to scrub hard for a living.
One who labors hard and lives meanly; a mean fellow.
One who, or that which, scrubs; esp., a brush used in scrubbing.
A gas washer. See under Gas.
Of the nature of scrub; small and mean; stunted in growth; as, a scrubby cur.
The nape of the neck; the loose outside skin, as of the back of the neck.
Nice; particular; fastidious; excellent; fine.
To scranch; to crunch.
Hence, a very small quantity; a particle.
To excite scruples in; to cause to scruple.
To perplex with scruples; to regard with scruples.
Careful; cautious; exact; nice; as, scrupulous abstinence from labor; scrupulous performance of duties.
One who scrutinizes; a close examiner or inquirer.
To examine closely; to inspect or observe with critical attention; to regard narrowly; as, to scrutinize the measures of administration; to scrutinize the conduct or motives of individuals.
Closely examining, or inquiring; careful; sctrict.
Close examination; minute inspection; critical observation.
A escritoire; a writing desk.
To squeeze, compress, crush, or bruise.
A cry or shout.
Loose, vapory clouds driven swiftly by the wind.
A silver coin, and money of account, used in Italy and Sicily, varying in value, in different parts, but worth about 4 shillings sterling, or about 96 cents; also, a gold coin worth about the same.
The back part of the neck; the scruff.
To strive or struggle with a close grapple; to wrestle in a rough fashion.
Hence, to strive or contend tumultuously; to struggle confusedly or at haphazard.
Hence, a confused contest; a tumultuous struggle for superiority; a fight.
An agricultural implement resembling a scarifier, but usually lighter.
A shoal of fish.
The common skua gull.
To impel a boat with a scull or sculls.
A boat rowed by one man with two sculls, or short oars.
Hence, refuse; fifth; offal.
A servant who cleans pots and kettles, and does other menial services in the kitchen.
Hence, an artist who designs works of sculpture, his first studies and his finished model being usually in a plastic material, from which model the marble is cut, or the bronze is cast.
Of or pertaining to sculpture.
Carved work modeled of, or cut upon, wood, stone, metal, etc.
The extraneous matter or impurities which rise to the surface of liquids in boiling or fermentation, or which form on the surface by other means; also, the scoria of metals in a molten state; dross.
To sweep or range over the surface of.

To cover lighty, as a painting, or a drawing, with a thin wash of opaque color, or with color-crayon dust rubbed on with the stump, or to make any similar additions to the work, so as to produce a softened effect.

A mode of obtaining a softened effect, in painting and drawing, by the application of a thin layer of opaque color to the surface of a painting, or part of the surface, which is too bright in color, or which requires harmonizing.
The color so laid on. Also used figuratively.
An instrument for taking off scum; a skimmer.
The act of taking off scum.
Covered with scum; of the nature of scum.
To have a feeling of loathing or disgust; hence, to have dislike, prejudice, or reluctance.

A marine sparoid food fish (Stenotomus chrysops, or S. argyrops), common on the Atlantic coast of the United States. It appears bright silvery when swimming in the daytime, but shows broad blackish transverse bands at night and when dead. Called also porgee, paugy, porgy, scuppaug.
An opening cut through the waterway and bulwarks of a ship, so that water falling on deck may flow overboard; -- called also scupper hole.
To move hastily; to scour.
Hence, the foul remains of anything adherent.
Quality or state of being scurfy.
Such as befits a buffoon or vulgar jester; grossly opprobrious or loudly jocose in language; scurrilous; as, scurrile taunts.
That which is scurrile or scurrilous; gross or obscene language; low buffoonery; vulgar abuse.
Containing low indecency or abuse; mean; foul; vile; obscenely jocular; as, scurrilous language.
To hasten away or along; to move rapidly; to hurry; as, the rabbit scurried away.
Act of scurring; hurried movement.
In a scurvy manner.
The quality or state of being scurvy; vileness; meanness.
Covered or affected with scurf or scabs; scabby; scurfy; specifically, diseased with the scurvy.
Vile; mean; low; vulgar; contemptible.
Shield money; commutation of service for a sum of money. See Escuage.
Of or pertaining to a shield.
Protected or covered by bony or horny plates, or large scales.
To separate the woody fiber from (flax, hemp, etc.) by beating; to swingle.
The woody fiber of flax; the refuse of scutched flax.
An implement or machine for scutching hemp, flax, or cotton; etc.; a scutch; a scutching machine.
An old French gold coin of the value of 3s. 4d. sterling, or about 80 cents.
See Scutellum, n., 2.
Formed like a plate or salver; composed of platelike surfaces; as, the scutellated bone of a sturgeon.
Having the tarsi covered with broad transverse scales, or scutella; -- said of certain birds.
Having the form of a scutellum.
A rounded apothecium having an elevated rim formed of the proper thallus, the fructification of certain lichens.
The third of the four pieces forming the upper part of a thoracic segment of an insect. It follows the scutum, and is followed by the small postscutellum; a scutella. See Thorax.
One of the Scutibranchiata.
An order of gastropod Mollusca having a heart with two auricles and one ventricle. The shell may be either spiral or shieldlike.
Carrying a shield or buckler.
Any species of chilopod myriapods of the genus Scutigera. They sometimes enter buildings and prey upon insects.
Having the anterior surface of the tarsus covered with scutella, or transverse scales, in the form of incomplete bands terminating at a groove on each side; -- said of certain birds.
A broad, shallow basket.
A wide-mouthed vessel for holding coal: a coal hod.
The lid or door which covers or closes an opening in a roof, wall, or the like.
To sink by making holes through the bottom of; as, to scuttle a ship.
A penthouse or awning.
Arm scye, a cutter's term for the armhole or part of the armhole of the waist of a garnment.
To hide; to secrete; to conceal.

A dangerous rock on the Italian coast opposite the whirpool Charybdis on the coast of Sicily, -- both personified in classical literature as ravenous monsters. The passage between them was formerly considered perilous; hence, the saying "Between Scylla and Charybdis," signifying a great peril on either hand.
A genus of oceanic nudibranchiate mollusks having the small branched gills situated on the upper side of four fleshy lateral lobes, and on the median caudal crest.
A white crystalline substance of a sweetish taste, resembling inosite and metameric with dextrose. It is extracted from the kidney of the dogfish (of the genus Scylium), the shark, and the skate.
See Scyphus, 2 (b).
The young attached larva of Discophora in the stage when it resembles a hydroid, or actinian.
An order of fishes including the blennioid and gobioid fishes, and other related families.
Same as Acraspeda, or Discophora.
An order of fresh-water fishes inhabiting tropical Africa. They have rudimentary electrical organs on each side of the tail.
A kind of large drinking cup, -- used by Greeks and Romans, esp. by poor folk.
The cup of a narcissus, or a similar appendage to the corolla in other flowers.
Wilson's thrush; -- so called from its note.
Of or pertaining to Scythia (a name given to the northern part of Asia, and Europe adjoining to Asia), or its language or inhabitants.
The language of the Scythians.
An inland body of water, esp. if large or if salt or brackish; as, the Caspian Sea; the Sea of Aral; sometimes, a small fresh-water lake; as, the Sea of Galilee.
The European fifteen-spined stickleback (Gasterosteus spinachia); -- called also bismore.
See Drag sail, under 4th Drag.
Any one of numerous species of soft-bodied Anthozoa, belonging to the order Actrinaria; an actinian.
The fruit of a West Indian palm (Manicaria Plukenetii), often found floating in the sea.
A bank or mole to defend against the sea.

((Zo\'94l.) (a) A large marine food fish (Serranus, ∨ Centropristis, atrarius) which abounds on the Atlantic coast of the United States. It is dark bluish, with black bands, and more or less varied with small white spots and blotches. Called also, locally, blue bass, black sea bass, blackfish, bluefish, and black perch. (b) A California food fish (Cynoscion nobile); -- called also white sea bass, and sea salmon.
A beach lying along the sea.
Any fur seal. See under Fur.
A green seaweed (Cladophora rupestris) growing in dense tufts.
Any large marine mammal, as a seal, walrus, or cetacean.
Any swimming bird frequenting the sea; a sea fowl.
A plant (Su\'91da maritima) of the Goosefoot family, growing in salt marches.
A boat or vessel adapted to the open sea; hence, a vessel considered with reference to her power of resisting a storm, or maintaining herself in a heavy sea; as, a good sea boat.
Bordering on the sea; situated beside the sea.
See Marine rainbow, under Rainbow.
A boy employed on shipboard.
A breaking or overflow of a bank or a dike by the sea.
Same as Sea letter.
Built at, in, or by the sea.
See Sea kale, under Kale.
The beluga, or white whale.
The captain of a vessel that sails upon the sea.
Mariner's card, or compass.
A chart or map on which the lines of the shore, islands, shoals, harbors, etc., are delineated.
A fleshy plant (Arenaria peploides) growing in large tufts in the sands of the northern Atlantic seacoast; -- called also sea sandwort, and sea purslane.

Any one of the large bivalve mollusks found on the open seacoast, especially those of the family Mactrid\'91, as the common American species. (Mactra, ∨ Spisula, solidissima); -- called also beach clam, and surf clam.
Coal brought by sea; -- a name by which mineral coal was formerly designated in the south of England, in distinction from charcoal, which was brought by land.
In a steamship, a cock or valve close to the vessel's side, for closing a pipe which communicates with the sea.
A large blackfish seaweed (Agarum Turneri), the frond of which is punctured with many little holes.
The mariner's compass. See under Compass.
A yellow cylindrical mass of egg capsule of certain species of whelks (Buccinum), which resembles an ear of maize.
Any crustacean of the genus Palinurus and allied genera, as the European spiny lobster (P. vulgaris), which is much used as an article of food. See Lobster.
Any large holothurian, especially one of those belonging to the genus Pentacta, or Cucumaria, as the common American and European species. (P. frondosa).
The European sea perch.
A European amarylidaceous plant (Pancratium maritimum).
Any very large ray, especially any species of the genus Manta or Cepholoptera, some of which become more than twenty feet across and weigh several tons. See also Ox ray, under Ox.
An old sailor; a salt.
The little auk, or rotche. See Illust. of Rotche.
A dragonet, or sculpin.

Any one of numerous species of ducks which frequent the seacoasts and feed mainly on fishes and mollusks. The scoters, eiders, old squaw, and ruddy duck are examples. They may be distinguished by the lobate hind toe.

Any one of several species of fish-eating eagles of the genus Hali\'91etus and allied genera, as the North Pacific sea eagle. (H. pelagicus), which has white shoulders, head, rump, and tail; the European white-tailed eagle (H. albicilla); and the Indian white-tailed sea eagle, or fishing eagle (Polioa\'89tus ichthya\'89tus). The bald eagle and the osprey are also sometimes classed as sea eagles.
The eagle ray. See under Ray.

A very large seal (Macrorhinus proboscideus) of the Antarctic seas, much hunted for its oil. It sometimes attains a length of thirty feet, and is remarkable for the prolongation of the nose of the adult male into an erectile elastic proboscis, about a foot in length. Another species of smaller size (M. angustirostris) occurs on the coast of Lower California, but is now nearly extinct.
One who follows the sea as a business; a mariner; a sailor.
Following the business of a mariner; as, a seafaring man.
Any gorgonian which branches in a plumelike form.
Any gorgonian which branches like a fern.
An engagement between ships at sea; a naval battle.
A sertularian hydroid, especially Sertularia abietina, which branches like a miniature fir tree.
A sea anemone, or any related anthozoan.
Foam of sea water.
Meerschaum; -- called also sea froth.
The thrasher shark. See Thrasher.
See Sea foam, 2.
A long, rolling swell of the sea.
Any small holothurian resembling in form a gherkin.
A hydroid coral of the genus Millepora, especially M. alcicornis, of the West Indies and Florida. So called because it stings the tongue like ginger. See Illust. under Millepore.
A kind of kelp (Laminaria digitata) with palmately cleft fronds; -- called also sea wand, seaware, and tangle.
Surrounded by the water of the sea or ocean; as, a seagirt isle.
A goddess supposed to live in or reign over the sea, or some part of the sea.
Going upon the sea; especially, sailing upon the deep sea; -- used in distinction from coasting or river, as applied to vessels.
A gown or frock with short sleeves, formerly worn by mariners.
The clusters of gelatinous egg capsules of a squid (Loligo).
The green color of sea water.
Of a beautiful bluish green color, like sea water on soundings.
The European black goby (Gobius niger).
Any gull living on the seacoast.
A Jewish dry measure containing one third of an an ephah.
Any tectibranchiate mollusk of the genus Aplysia. See Aplysia.
A low perennial plant (Frankenia l\'91vis) resembling heath, growing along the seashore in Europe.
the common guillemot; -- applied also to various other sea birds.
An evergeen seashore plant (Eryngium maritimum). See Eryngium.
A small uninhabited island.
A fabulous creature, half horse and half fish, represented in classic mythology as driven by sea dogs or ridden by the Nereids. It is also depicted in heraldry. See Hippocampus.
Of or pertaining to certain islands along the coast of South Carolina and Georgia; as, sea-island cotton, a superior cotton of long fiber produced on those islands.
A medusa, or jellyfish.
Soap prepared for use in milling cloth.
One of the leaders among the Norsemen who passed their lives in roving the seas in search of plunder and adventures; a Norse pirate chief. See the Note under Viking.
Any aquatic carnivorous mammal of the families Phocid\'91 and Otariid\'91.
Wax, wafer, or other tenacious substance, set to an instrument, and impressed or stamped with a seal; as, to give a deed under hand and seal.
To mark with a stamp, as an evidence of standard exactness, legal size, or merchantable quality; as, to seal weights and measures; to seal silverware.
The peculiar language or phraseology of seamen; sailor's cant.
The rock pipit (Anthus obscurus).
See Marsh rosemary, under Marsh.
The gray snapper. See under Snapper.
Of a rich dark brown color, like the fur of the fur seal after it is dyed.
Legs able to maintain their possessor upright in stormy weather at sea, that is, ability stand or walk steadily on deck when a vessel is rolling or pitching in a rough sea.
Any one of several species of spotted seals, especially Ogmorhinus leptonyx, and Leptonychotes Weddelli, of the Antarctic Ocean. The North Pacific sea leopard is the harbor seal.
One who seals; especially, an officer whose duty it is to seal writs or instruments, to stamp weights and measures, or the like.
A mariner or a vessel engaged in the business of capturing seals.
The customary certificate of national character which neutral merchant vessels are bound to carry in time of war; a passport for a vessel and cargo.
The green papery fronds of several seaweeds of the genus Ulva, sometimes used as food.
The level of the surface of the sea; any surface on the same level with the sea.
A compound of the resinous materials, pigments, etc., used as a material for seals, as for letters, documents, etc.

Any one of several large species of seals of the family Otariid\'91 native of the Pacific Ocean, especially the southern sea lion (Otaria jubata) of the South American coast; the northern sea lion (Eumetopias Stelleri) found from California to Japan; and the black, or California, sea lion (Zalophus Californianus), which is common on the rocks near San Francisco.
The three-bearded rockling. See Rockling.
Any one of numerous species of isopod crustaceans of Cymothoa, Livoneca, and allied genera, mostly parasites on fishes.
Hence, a line of junction; a joint; a suture, as on a ship, a floor, or other structure; the line of union, or joint, of two boards, planks, metal plates, etc.
To mark with something resembling a seam; to line; to scar.
A merman; the male of the mermaid.
The skill of a good seaman; the art, or skill in the art, of working a ship.
Out of condition; not in good condition; -- said of a hawk.
A gull; the mew.
A geographical mile. See Mile.
A low, fleshy perennial herb (Glaux maritima) found along northern seashores.
The act or process of forming a seam or joint.
The cord or rope at the margin of a seine, to which the meshes of the net are attached.
Any large sea animal.
Any branched marine bryozoan resembling moss.
A dorsibranchiate annelid, belonging to Aphrodite and allied genera, having long, slender, hairlike set\'91 on the sides
One who sews well, or whose occupation is to sew.
A woman whose occupation is sewing; a needlewoman.
The business of a seamstress.
A rich slimy deposit in salt marshes and along the seashore, sometimes used as a manure; -- called also sea ooze.
Having a seam; containing seams, or showing them.
A session, as of some public body; especially, a meeting of spiritualists to receive spirit communication, so called.
A jellyfish, or medusa.
A bard among the Highlanders of Scotland, who preserved and repeated the traditions of the tribes; also, a genealogist.
The officinal squill. See Squill.
Same as Sea mud.

An aquatic carnivore (Enhydris lutris, ∨ marina) found in the North Pacific Ocean.  Its fur is highly valued, especially by the Chinese. It is allied to the common otter, but is larger, with feet more decidedly webbed.
The gilthead (Crenilabrus melops), a fish of the British coasts.
A document carried by neutral merchant vessels in time of war, to show their nationality; a sea letter or passport. See Passport.
A beautiful American ascidian (Cynthia, ∨ Halocynthia, pyriformis) having the size, form, velvety surface, and color of a ripe peach.
A pedunculated ascidian of the genus Boltonia.
The European bass (Roccus, ∨ Labrax, lupus); -- called also sea dace.
The oyster catcher, a limicoline bird of the genus H\'91matopus.
A dish of crust or pastry and meat or fish, etc., cooked together in alternate layers, -- a common food of sailors; as, a three-decker sea pie.
A picture representing a scene at sea; a marine picture.
A porpoise or dolphin.
A pool of salt water.
Any fish of the genus Diodon, and allied genera, whose body is covered with spines. See Illust. under Diodon.
An American compound ascidian (Amor\'91cium stellatum) which forms large whitish masses resembling salt pork.
A port on the seashore, or one accessible for seagoing vessels. Also used adjectively; as, a seaport town.
The horny egg case of a skate, and of certain sharks.
See 1st Sea pie.
See 1st Sea pie.
A quaking of the sea.

[OE. seer, AS. se\'a0r (assumed) fr. se\'a0rian to wither; akin to D. zoor dry, LG. soor, OHG. sor&emac;n to to wither, Gr. sush) to dry, to wither, Zend hush to dry. &root;152. Cf. Austere, Sorrel, a.] Dry; withered; no longer green; -- applied to leaves.

To burn (the surface of) to dryness and hardness; to cauterize; to expose to a degree of heat such as changes the color or the hardness and texture of the surface; to scorch; to make callous; as, to sear the skin or flesh. Also used figuratively.
To sift; to bolt.
A searce, or sieve.
Quality of being searchable.
One who, or that which, searhes or examines; a seeker; an inquirer; an examiner; a trier.
Exploring thoroughly; scrutinizing; penetrating; trying; as, a searching discourse; a searching eye.
Scorched; cauterized; hence, figuratively, insensible; not susceptible to moral influences.
Risk of injury, destruction, or loss by the sea, or while at sea.
A pirate; a sea rover.
See under Robin, and Illustration in Appendix.
Room or space at sea for a vessel to maneuver, drive, or scud, without peril of running ashore or aground.
, a. Cruising at random on the ocean.
Common salt, obtained from sea water by evaporation.
Any marine saurian; esp. (Paleon.) the large extinct species of Mosasaurus, Icthyosaurus, Plesiosaurus, and related genera.
A picture representing a scene at sea.
Any bryozoan which forms rounded or irregular patches of coral on stones, seaweeds, etc.
Any marine snake. See Sea snake.
A large marine animal of unknown nature, often reported to have been seen at sea, but never yet captured.
The coast of the sea; the land that lies adjacent to the sea or ocean.
All the ground between the ordinary highwater and low-water marks.
The peculiar sickness, characterized by nausea and prostration, which is caused by the pitching or rolling of a vessel.
The land bordering on, or adjacent to, the sea; the seashore. Also used adjectively.
Any isopod crustacean of the genus Ligia.
A small fish of the genus Liparis, having a ventral sucker. It lives among stones and seaweeds.

Any one of many species of venomous aquatic snakes of the family Hydrophid\'91, having a flattened tail and living entirely in the sea, especially in the warmer parts of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. They feed upon fishes, and are mostly of moderate size, but some species become eight or ten feet long and four inches broad.
A sandpiper, as the knot and dunlin.

One of the divisions of the year, marked by alternations in the length of day and night, or by distinct conditions of temperature, moisture, etc., caused mainly by the relative position of the earth with respect to the sun. In the north temperate zone, four seasons, namely, spring, summer, autumn, and winter, are generally recognized. Some parts of the world have three seasons, -- the dry, the rainy, and the cold; other parts have but two, -- the dry and the rainy.
Hence, a period of time, especially as regards its fitness for anything contemplated or done; a suitable or convenient time; proper conjuncture; as, the season for planting; the season for rest.
To fit for any use by time or habit; to habituate; to accustom; to inure; to ripen; to mature; as, to season one to a climate.
To become dry and hard, by the escape of the natural juices, or by being penetrated with other substance; as, timber seasons in the sun.
The act or process by which anything is seasoned.
That which is added to any species of food, to give it a higher relish, as salt, spices, etc.; a condiment.
Any maioid crab; a spider crab. See Maioid, and Spider crab, under Spider.
An ascidian. See Illust. under Tunicata.
A starfish, or brittle star.
See Cornish chough, under Chough.
The place occupied by anything, or where any person or thing is situated, resides, or abides; a site; an abode, a station; a post; a situation.
To cause to occupy a post, site, situation, or the like; to station; to establish; to fix; to settle.
The act of providong with a seat or seats; as, the seating of an audience.
The act of making seats; also, the material for making seats; as, cane seating.
Any one of several species of true trouts which descend rivers and enter the sea after spawning, as the European bull trout and salmon trout, and the eastern American spotted trout.
A great blackish seaweed of the Southern Ocean, having a hollow and expanding stem and a pinnate frond, sometimes twenty feet long.
Any large marine univalve shell of the genus Triton. See Triton.
Any one of numerous species of echinoderms of the order Echinoidea.
A wall, or embankment, to resist encroachments of the sea.
Surrounded, bounded, or protected by the sea, as if by a wall.
Directed or situated toward the sea.
Popularly, any plant or plants growing in the sea.
Any marine plant of the class Alg\'91, as kelp, dulse, Fucus, Ulva, etc.
A European wrasse (Labrus vetula).
A gorgonian coral with long flexible branches.
A wing shell (Avicula).
(Bot.) A kind of bindweed (Convolvulus Soldanella) growing on the seacoast of Europe.
A European species of wormwood (Artemisia maritima) growing by the sea.
The state or quality of being seaworthy, or able to resist the ordinary violence of wind and weather.
Pertaining to, or secreting, fat; composed of fat; having the appearance of fat; as, the sebaceous secretions of some plants, or the sebaceous humor of animals.
The eleventh month of the ancient Hebrew year, approximately corresponding with February.
The mucilaginous drupaceous fruit of two East Indian trees (Cordia Myxa, and C. latifolia), sometimes used medicinally in pectoral diseases.
Producing fat; sebaceous; as, the sebiferous, or sebaceous, glands.
A morbidly increased discharge of sebaceous matter upon the skin; stearrhea.
A genus of cereal grasses including rye.
A cutting; an intersection; as, the point of secancy of one line by another.
A line that cuts another; especially, a straight line cutting a curve in two or more points.

A right line drawn from the center of a circle through one end of a circular arc, and terminated by a tangent drawn from the other end; the number expressing the ratio line of this line to the radius of the circle. See Trigonometrical function, under Function.
One of a numerous body of Presbyterians in Scotland who seceded from the communion of the Established Church, about the year 1733, and formed the Secession Church, so called.
To secrete; as, mucus secerned in the nose.
That which promotes secretion.
A vessel in, or by means of, which the process of secretion takes place; a secreting vessel.
The withdrawal of a State from the national Union.
One who upholds secession.
One who holds to the belief that a State has the right to separate from the Union at its will.
Barren; unprofitable. See Rent seck, under Rent.
A small reddish brown sweet and juicy pear. It originated on a farm near Philadelphia, afterwards owned by a Mr. Seckel.
Immediately following the first; next to the first in order of place or time; hence, occuring again; another; other.
Next to the first in value, power, excellence, dignity, or rank; secondary; subordinate; inferior.
Secondly; in the second place.
One who seconds or supports what another attempts, affirms, moves, or proposes; as, the seconder of an enterprise or of a motion.
Not original or primary; received from another.
Not new; already or previously or used by another; as, a secondhand book, garment.
The second part in a concerted piece.
Of the second size, rank, quality, or value; as, a second-rate ship; second-rate cloth; a second-rate champion.
One who keeps, or is intrusted with, secrets.

A person employed to write orders, letters, dispatches, public or private papers, records, and the like; an official scribe, amanuensis, or writer; one who attends to correspondence, and transacts other business, for an association, a public body, or an individual.
To deposit in a place of hiding; to hide; to conceal; as, to secrete stolen goods; to secrete one's self.
To separate from the blood and elaborate by the process of secretion; to elaborate and emit as a secretion. See Secretion.

The act of secreting; the process by which material is separated from the blood through the agency of the cells of the various glands and elaborated by the cells into new substances so as to form the various secretions, as the saliva, bile, and other digestive fluids. The process varies in the different glands, and hence are formed the various secretions.
Parted by animal secretion; as, secretitious humors.
The quality of being secretive; disposition or tendency to conceal.
The faculty or propensity which impels to reserve, secrecy, or concealment.
The state or quality of being secret, hid, or concealed.
Secreting; performing, or connected with, the office secretion; secernent; as, secretory vessels, nerves.
A cutting; a scion.
Pertaining to a sect, or to sects; peculiar to a sect; bigotedly attached to the tenets and interests of a denomination; as, sectarian principles or prejudices.

One of a sect; a member or adherent of a special school, denomination, or religious or philosophical party; one of a party in religion which has separated itself from established church, or which holds tenets different from those of the prevailing denomination in a state.
To imbue with sectarian feelings; to subject to the control of a sect.
The state or quality of being sectile.
The act of cutting, or separation by cutting; as, the section of bodies.
A part separated from something; a division; a portion; a slice.
Consisting of sections, or capable of being divided into sections; as, a sectional steam boiler.
The state or quality of being sectional; sectionalism.
To divide according to gepgraphical sections or local interests.
To form into sections.
Devotion to a sect.
One devoted to a sect; a soetary.
A little or petty sect.

A mathematical instrument, consisting of two rulers connected at one end by a joint, each arm marked with several scales, as of equal parts, chords, sines, tangents, etc., one scale of each kind on each arm, and all on lines radiating from the common center of motion. The sector is used for plotting, etc., to any scale.
Coming or observed once in an age or a century.
Pertaining to an age, or the progress of ages, or to a long period of time; accomplished in a long progress of time; as, secular inequality; the secular refrigeration of the globe.
A church official whose functions are confined to the vocal department of the choir.
The tenets or principles of the secularists.
Supreme attention to the things of the present life; worldliness.
To convert from spiritual or common use; as, to secularize a church, or church property.
The quality or state of being secular; worldliness; worldly-minded-ness.
Arranged on one side only, as flowers or leaves on a stalk.
The second coat, or integument, of an ovule, lying within the primine.
The afterbirth, or placenta and membranes; -- generally used in the plural.
Free from fear, care, or anxiety; easy in mind; not feeling suspicion or distrust; confident.
Overconfident; incautious; careless; -- in a bad sense.
One who, or that which, secures.
Having the form of an ax hatchet.
One of a family of beetles having the maxillary palpi terminating in a hatchet-shaped joint.
The condition or quality of being secure; secureness.
Undisturbed by passion or caprice; calm; tranquil; serene; not passionate or giddy; composed; staid; as, a sedate soul, mind, or temper.
A remedy which allays irritability and irritation, and irritative activity or pain.
In a sedentary manner.
Quality of being sedentary.
Accustomed to sit much or long; as, a sedentary man.
Characterized by, or requiring, much sitting; as, a sedentary employment; a sedentary life.
A flock of herons.
The material of which sedimentary rocks are formed.
Of or pertaining to sediment; formed by sediment; containing matter that has subsided.

The raising of commotion in a state, not amounting to insurrection; conduct tending to treason, but without an overt act; excitement of discontent against the government, or of resistance to lawful authority.
Disposed to arouse, or take part in, violent opposition to lawful authority; turbulent; factious; guilty of sedition; as, seditious citizens.
To draw aside from the path of rectitude and duty in any manner; to entice to evil; to lead astray; to tempt and lead to iniquity; to corrupt.
Specifically, to induce to surrender chastity; to debauch by means of solicitation.
The means employed to seduce, as flattery, promises, deception, etc.; arts of enticing or corrupting.

The act of seducing; enticement to wrong doing; specifically, the offense of inducing a woman to consent to unlawful sexual intercourse, by enticements which overcome her scruples; the wrong or crime of persuading a woman to surrender her chastity.
That which seduces, or is adapted to seduce; means of leading astray; as, the seductions of wealth.
A woman who seduces.
The quality or state of being sedulous; diligent and assiduous application; constant attention; unremitting industry; sedulousness.
To perceive by mental vision; to form an idea or conception of; to note with the mind; to observe; to discern; to distinguish; to understand; to comprehend; to ascertain.
Figuratively: To have intellectual apprehension; to perceive; to know; to understand; to discern; -- often followed by a preposition, as through, or into.
To cover thinly with something scattered; to ornament with seedlike decorations.
A sweet cake or cooky containing aromatic seeds, as caraway.
One who, or that which, sows or plants seed.
The quality or state of being seedy, shabby, or worn out; a state of wretchedness or exhaustion.
Without seed or seeds.
A plant reared from the seed, as distinguished from one propagated by layers, buds, or the like.
A vessel in which a sower carries the seed to be scattered.
Having a peculiar flavor supposed to be derived from the weeds growing among the vines; -- said of certain kinds of FRench brandy.
To inquire for; to ask for; to solicit; to bessech.
One of a small heterogeneous sect of the 17th century, in Great Britain, who professed to be seeking the true church, ministry, and sacraments.
One who contrives to give himself vexation.
Time; season; as, hay seel.
The quality or state of being seemly: comeliness; propriety.
Oozy; -- applied to land under cultivation that is not well drained.
A scombroid food fish of Maderia (Cybium Commersonii).
A kind of muslin of a texture between nainsook and mull.
The office or quality of a seer.
A light fabric, originally made in the East Indies, of silk and linen, usually having alternating stripes, and a slightly craped or puckered surface; also, a cotton fabric of similar appearance.
A plank or board adjusted for this play.
To cause to move backward and forward in seesaw fashion.
The gladen, and other species of Iris.
A case or holder made of fire clay, in which fine pottery is inclosed while baking in the kin.

A part cut off from a figure by a line or plane; especially, that part of a circle contained between a chord and an arc of that circle, or so much of the circle as is cut off by the chord; as, the segment acb in the Illustration.
Relating to, or being, a segment.
Of or pertaining to the segments of animals; as, a segmental duct; segmental papill\'91.
A sign. See Al segno, and Dal segno.
A liliaceous plant (Calochortus Nuttallii) of Western North America, and its edible bulb; -- so called by the Ute Indians and the Mormons.
Separated from others of the same kind.
The act of segregating, or the state of being segregated; separation from others; a parting.
Separation from a mass, and gathering about centers or into cavities at hand through cohesive attraction or the crystallizing process.
A descendant of Mohammed through his daughter Fatima and nephew Ali.
Of or pertaining to Seidlitz, a village in Bohemia.
Vested with large powers; independent.
A title of honor or of address in the South of Europe, corresponding to Sir or Mr. in English.
A share of the receipts of a business taken in payment for the use of a right, as a copyright or a patent.
To lord it over.
The territory over which a lord holds jurisdiction; a manor.
Fishing with a seine.
One of several spores arranged in a chain as in certain alg\'91 of the genus Callithamnion.
Of or pertaining to a seismograph; indicated by a seismograph.
A writing about, or a description of, earthquakes.
The art of registering the shocks and undulatory movements of earthquakes.
The science of earthquakes.
An instrument for measuring the direction, duration, and force of earthquakes and like concussions.
Of or pertaining to seismometry, or seismometer; as, seismometric instruments; seismometric measurements.
The mensuration of such phenomena of earthquakes as can be expressed in numbers, or by their relation to the co\'94rdinates of space.
Something peculiar to one's self.
To fall or rush upon suddenly and lay hold of; to gripe or grasp suddenly; to reach and grasp.

Possession; possession of an estate of froehold. It may be either in deed or in law; the former when there is actual possession, the latter when there is a right to such possession by construction of law. In some of the United States seizin means merely ownership.
The act of taking possession.
The operation of fastening together or lashing.
The act of seizing, or the state of being seized; sudden and violent grasp or gripe; a taking into possession; as, the seizure of a thief, a property, a throne, etc.
Retention within one's grasp or power; hold; possession; ownership.
The act of disjoining, or the state of being disjoined.
One of the Selachii. See Illustration in Appendix.
An order of elasmobranchs including the sharks and rays; the Plagiostomi. Called also Selacha, Selache, and Selachoidei.
A division of ganoid fishes which includes the paddlefish, in which the mouth is armed with small teeth.
A genus of cryptogamous plants resembling Lycopodia, but producing two kinds of spores; also, any plant of this genus. Many species are cultivated in conservatories.
A word of doubtful meaning, occuring frequently in the Psalms; by some, supposed to signify silence or a pause in the musical performance of the song.
The act of selecting, or the state of being selected; choice, by preference.
That which is selected; a collection of things chosen; as, a choice selection of books.
A salt of selenic acid; -- formerly called also seleniate.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, hydrogen selenide, H2Se, regarded as an acid analogous to sulphydric acid.
Of or pertaining to selenium; derived from, or containing, selenium; specifically, designating those compounds in which the element has a higher valence as contrasted with selenious compounds.
A binary compound of selenium, or a compound regarded as binary; as, ethyl selenide.
Containing, or impregnated with, selenium; as, seleniferous pyrites.
A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting the presence of selenium or its compounds; as, selenio-phosphate, a phosphate having selenium in place of all, or a part, of the oxygen.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, selenium; specifically, designating those compounds in which the element has a lower valence as contrasted with selenic compounds.
A salt of selenious acid.
A variety of gypsum, occuring in transparent crystals or crystalline masses.
Of or pertaining to selenite; resembling or containing selenite.

A nonmetallic element of the sulphur group, and analogous to sulphur in its compounds. It is found in small quantities with sulphur and some sulphur ores, and obtained in the free state as a dark reddish powder or crystalline mass, or as a dark metallic-looking substance. It exhibits under the action of light a remarkable variation in electric conductivity, and is used in certain electric apparatus. Symbol Se. Atomic weight 78.9.
Combined with selenium as in a selenide; as, seleniureted hydrogen.
As seen or estimated from the center of the moon; with the moon central.
, n. A picture or delineation of the moon's surface, or of any part of it.
One skilled in selenography.
The science that treats of the physical features of the moon; -- corresponding to physical geography in respect to the earth.
That branch of astronomy which treats of the moon.
Same; particular; very; identical.
Degradation of one's self by one's own act.
Humiliation or abasement proceeding from consciousness of inferiority, guilt, or shame.
Abhorrence of one's self.
The abuse of one's own self, powers, or faculties.
Action by, or originating in, one's self or itself.
Acting of one's self or of itself; acting without depending on other agents.
The quality or state of being self-active; self-action.
Capable of assuming a desired position or condition with relation to other parts, under varying circumstances, without requiring to be adjusted by hand; -- said of a piece in machinery.
One's own affairs; one's private business.
Annihilated by one's self.
Annihilation by one's own acts; annihilation of one's desires.
Applying to or by one's self.
Approving one's own action or character by one's own judgment.
The act of asserting one's self, or one's own rights or claims; the quality of being self-asserting.
Disposed to self-assertion; self-asserting.
Assumed by one's own act, or without authority.
Assured by or of one's self; self-reliant; complacent.
Begotten by one's self, or one's own powers.
Born or produced by one's self.
Centered in itself, or in one's self.\'3c-- of people? --\'3e
The quality or state of being self-centered.
Being of a single color; -- applied to flowers, animals, and textile fabrics.
Control over one's own feelings, temper, etc.; self-control.
Imparting or communicating by its own powers.
Communion with one's self; thoughts about one's self.
The quality of being self-complacent.
Conceit of one's self; an overweening opinion of one's powers or endowments.
Concern for one's self.
Condemnation of one's self by one's own judgment.
The quality or state of being self-confident; self-reliance.
Having the two things that are conjugate parts of the same figure; as, self-conjugate triangles.
Conscious of one's acts or state as belonging to, or originating in, one's self.
Conscious of one's self as an object of the observation of others; as, the speaker was too self-conscious.
Considering in one's own mind; deliberating.
Consistent with one's self or with itself; not deviation from the ordinary standard by which the conduct is guided; logically consistent throughout; having each part consistent with the rest.
Consuming one's self or itself.
Having self-control; reserved; uncommunicative; wholly engrossed in one's self.

Having all the essential working parts connected by a bedplate or framework, or contained in a case, etc., so that mutual relations of the parts do not depend upon fastening outside of the machine itself.
Contradicting one's self or itself.
Control of one's self; restraint exercised over one's self; self-command.
Convicted by one's own consciousness, knowledge, avowal, or acts.
The act of convicting one's self, or the state of being self-convicted.
Created by one's self; not formed or constituted by another.
Culture, training, or education of one's self by one's own efforts.
The act of deceiving one's self, or the state of being self-deceived; self-deception.
Deceived or misled respecting one's self by one's own mistake or error.
The act of defending one's own person, property, or reputation.
The act of degrading one's self, or the state of being so degraded.
Accusation of one's self.
The denial of one's self; forbearing to gratify one's own desires; self-sacrifice.
Refusing to gratify one's self; self-sacrificing.
Dependent on one's self; self-depending; self-reliant.
Depending on one's self.
Corrupted or depraved by one's self.
The destruction of one's self; self-murder; suicide.
Determination by one's self; or, determination of one's acts or states without the necessitating force of motives; -- applied to the voluntary or activity.
Capable of self-determination; as, the self-determining power of will.
Devised by one's self.
Devoted in person, or by one's own will.
The act of devoting one's self, or the state of being self-devoted; willingness to sacrifice one's own advantage or happiness for the sake of others; self-sacrifice.
Devouring one's self or itself.
Want of confidence in one' self; diffidence.
Educated by one's own efforts, without instruction, or without pecuniary assistance from others.
Having the right of electing one's self, or, as a body, of electing its own members.
Enjoyment of one's self; self-satisfaction.
The holding a good opinion of one's self; self-complacency.
The act of estimating one's self; self-esteem.
The quality or state of being self-evident.
Evolution of one's self; development by inherent quality or power.
The act of exalting one's self, or the state of being so exalted.
One who examines himself; one given to self-examination.
Inherent existence; existence possessed by virtue of a being's own nature, and independent of any other being or cause; -- an attribute peculiar to God.
Explaining itself; capable of being understood without explanation.
The act of exposing one's self; the state of being so exposed.
The fertilization of a flower by pollen from the same flower and without outer aid; autogamy.
Fertilized by pollen from the same flower.
Springing from vainglory or vanity; vain; boastful.
Hence, government of a community, state, or nation by the joint action of the mass of people constituting such a civil body; also, the state of being so governed; democratic government; democracy.
A blue-flowered labiate plant (Brunella vulgaris); the healall.
Having the power or property of healing itself.
The act of aiding one's self, without depending on the aid of others.
The act of killing one's self; suicide.
Ignorant of one's self.
Imparting by one's own, or by its own, powers and will.
Having or manifesting an exaggerated idea of one's own importance or merit.
Voluntarily taken on one's self; as, self-imposed tasks.
Imposture practiced on one's self; self-deceit.
Indulging one's appetites, desires, etc., freely.
Private interest; the interest or advantage of one's self.
Particularly concerned for one's own interest or happiness.
Involution in one's self; hence, abstraction of thought; reverie.
Caring supremely or unduly for one's self; regarding one's own comfort, advantage, etc., in disregard, or at the expense, of those of others.

The quality or state of being selfish; exclusive regard to one's own interest or happiness; that supreme self-love or self-preference which leads a person to direct his purposes to the advancement of his own interest, power, or happiness, without regarding those of others.
Knowing of itself, without help from another.
Having no regard to self; unselfish.
Life for one's self; living solely or chiefly for one's own pleasure or good.
The love of one's self; desire of personal happiness; tendency to seek one's own benefit or advantage.
Moving by inherent power, without the aid of external impulse.
A neglecting of one's self, or of one's own interests.
That partiality to himself by which a man overrates his own worth when compared with others.
Disposed or arranged by an action originating in one's self or in itself.
The possession of one's powers; calmness; self-command; presence of mind; composure.
Praise of one's self.
The preservation of one's self from destruction or injury.
Propagating by one's self or by itself.

Registering itself; -- said of any instrument so contrived as to record its own indications of phenomena, whether continuously or at stated times, as at the maxima and minima of variations; as, a self-registering anemometer or barometer.
Regulated by one's self or by itself.
Tending or serving to regulate one's self or itself.
Reliant upon one's self; trusting to one's own powers or judgment.
The act of renouncing, or setting aside, one's own wishes, claims, etc.; self-sacrifice.
The quality or state of being self-repelling.
Made up of parts, as molecules or atoms, which mutually repel each other; as, gases are self-repelling.
The act of reproaching one's self; censure by one's own conscience.
Reproached by one's own conscience or judgment.
The act of reproving one's self; censure of one's conduct by one's own judgment.
Reproved by one's own conscience or one's own sense of guilt.
Reproving one's self; reproving by consciousness of guilt.
In a self-reproving way.
Respect for one's self; regard for one's character; laudable self-esteem.
Restrained by one's self or itself; restrained by one's own power or will.
Restraint over one's self; self-control; self-command.
A reverent respect for one's self.
The quality or state of being self-righteous; pharisaism.
The act of sacrificing one's self, or one's interest, for others; self-devotion.
Yielding up one's own interest, ffeelings, etc; sacrificing one's self.
Precisely the same; the very same; identical.
Satisfied with one's self or one's actions; self-complacent.
Giving satisfaction to one's self.
One who seeks only his own interest, advantage, or pleasure.
Seeking one's own interest or happiness; selfish.
Sufficient for one's self without external aid or co\'94peration.
Having an overweening confidence in one's own abilities or worth; hence, haughty; overbearing.
One who torments himself.
The act of inflicting pain on one's self; pain inflicted on one's self.
Faith in one's self; self-reliance.
One with itself; separate from others.
One's own will, esp. when opposed to that of others; obstinacy.
Governed by one's own will; not yielding to the wishes of others; obstinate.
Wrong done by a person himself.

Of or pertaining to Seljuk, a Tartar chief who embraced Mohammedanism, and began the subjection of Western Asia to that faith and rule; of or pertaining to the dynasty founded by him, or the empire maintained by his descendants from the 10th to the 13th century.
A throne or lofty seat.
To be sold; as, corn sells at a good price.
The edge of cloth which is woven in such a manner as to prevent raveling.
The edge plate of a lock, through which the bolt passes.
A skein or hank of rope yarns wound round with yarns or marline, -- used for stoppers, straps, etc.
A signal telegraph; an apparatus for giving signals by the disposition of lanterns, flags, oscillating arms, etc.
Of or pertaining to a semaphore, or semaphores; telegraphic.
By means a semaphore.
One who manages or operates a semaphore.
The doctrine of signs as the expression of thought or reasoning; the science of indicating thought by signs.
Likeness; resemblance, actual or apparent; similitude; as, the semblance of worth; semblance of virtue.
Seeming, rather than real; apparent.

It seems; -- chiefly used impersonally in reports and judgments to express an opinion in reference to the law on some point not necessary to be decided, and not intended to be definitely settled in the cause.
A description of the signs of disease.
Of or pertaining to the science of signs, or the systematic use of signs; as, a semeiological classification of the signs or symptoms of disease; a semeiological arrangement of signs used as signals.
The science or art of signs.
Relating to signs or indications; pertaining to the language of signs, or to language generally as indicating thought.
Of or pertaining to the signs or symptoms of diseases.
A daughter of Cadmus, and by Zeus mother of Bacchus.
The seed of plants.

The seed or fecundating fluid of male animals; sperm. It is a white or whitish viscid fluid secreted by the testes, characterized by the presence of spermatozoids to which it owes its generative power.
A prefix signifying half, and sometimes partly or imperfectly; as, semiannual, half yearly; semitransparent, imperfectly transparent.
Partially amplexicaul; embracing the stem half round, as a leaf.
The half of a given, or measuring, angle.
Having the figure of a half circle; forming a semicircle.
Of or pertaining to Semi-Arianism.
The doctrines or tenets of the Semi-Arians.
One half of the axis of an <?/llipse or other figure.
Half barbarous; partially civilized.
Half barbarous or uncivilized; as, semibarbaric display.
The quality or state of being half barbarous or uncivilized.
A note of half the time or duration of the breve; -- now usually called a whole note. It is the longest note in general use.
A bull issued by a pope in the period between his election and coronation.
Half or partially calcareous; as, a semicalcareous plant.
Half calcined; as, semicalcined iron.
To deprive of one testicle.
Of or pertaining to half of a century, or a period of fifty years; as, a semicentennial commemoration.
A half chorus; a passage to be sung by a selected portion of the voices, as the female voices only, in contrast with the full choir.
The half of a circle; the part of a circle bounded by its diameter and half of its circumference.
A body in the form of half of a circle, or half of a circumference.
A semicircular hollow or opening among trees or hills.
A half column; a column bisected longitudinally, or along its axis.
Like a semicolumn; flat on one side and round on the other; imperfectly columnar.
Half compact; imperfectly indurated.
Half conscious; imperfectly conscious.
Half crystalline; -- said of certain cruptive rocks composed partly of crystalline, partly of amorphous matter.
Of or pertaining to the square root of the cube of a quantity.
Half deisticsl; bordering on deism.
Half detached; partly distinct or separate.
An imperfect or diminished fifth.
A lesser third, having its terms as 6 to 5; a hemiditone.
Pertaining to, or accomplished in, half a day, or twelve hours; occurring twice every day.
Pertaining to, or traversed in, six hours, or in half the time between the rising and setting of a heavenly body; as, a semidiurnal arc.
An office or feast celebrated with less solemnity than the double ones. See Double, n., 8.
Having the outermost stamens converted into petals, while the inner ones remain perfect; -- said of a flower.
That which is part fable and part truth; a mixture of truth and fable.
A floscule, or florest, with its corolla prolonged into a strap-shaped petal; -- called also semifloret.
Having all the florets ligulate, as in the dandelion.
A half form; an imperfect form.
Half formed; imperfectly formed; as, semiformed crystals.

A peptonelike body, insoluble in alcohol, formed by boiling collagen or gelatin for a long time in water. Hemicollin, a like body, is also formed at the same time, and differs from semiglutin by being partly soluble in alcohol.
Half or party historical.
Imperfectly indurated or hardened.
Imperfectly changed into stone.
Half lenticular or convex; imperfectly resembling a lens.
The quality or state of being semiliquid; partial liquidity.
Half logical; partly logical; said of fallacies.
Shaped like a half moon.
The half of a lune.
An element possessing metallic properties in an inferior degree and not malleable, as arsenic, antimony, bismuth, molybdenum, uranium, etc.
Of or pertaining to a semimetal; possessing metallic properties in an inferior degree; resembling metal.
Coming or made twice in a month; as, semimonthly magazine; a semimonthly payment.
Having the faculty of speech but imperfectly developed or partially lost.
Pertaining to, containing, or consisting of, seed or semen; as, the seminal fluid.

Contained in seed; holding the relation of seed, source, or first principle; holding the first place in a series of developed results or consequents; germinal; radical; primary; original; as, seminal principles of generation; seminal virtue.
A piece of ground where seed is sown for producing plants for transplantation; a nursery; a seed plat.
To sow; to spread; to propagate.
Natural dispersion of seeds.
Forming or producing seed, or the male generative product of animals or of plants.
A tribe of Indians who formerly occupied Florida, where some of them still remain. They belonged to the Creek Confideration.
A carbohydrate of the glucose group found in the thickened endosperm of certain seeds, and extracted as yellow sirup having a sweetish-bitter taste.
The pupa of insects which undergo only a slight change in passing to the imago state.
Once in a while; on rare occasions.
Half official; having some official authority or importance; as, a semiofficial statement.
Same as Semeiography, Semeiology, Semeiological.
A variety of opal not possessing opalescence.
Half opaque; only half transparent.
Having the shape of a half orb or sphere.
Combined with oxygen only in part.
Having the anterior toes joined only part way down with a web; half-webbed; as, a semipalmate bird or foot. See Illust. k under Aves.
One branch of a parabola, being terminated at the principal vertex of the curve.
A half foot in poetry.
Containing a half foot.

A follower of John Cassianus, a French monk (died about 448), who modified the doctrines of Pelagius, by denying human merit, and maintaining the necessity of the Spirit's influence, while, on the other hand, he rejected the Augustinian doctrines of election, the inability of man to do good, and the certain perseverance of the saints.
Of or pertaining to the Semi-Pelagians, or their tenets.
Half clear, or imperfectly transparent; as, a semipellucid gem.
The qualiti or state of being imperfectly transparent.
Half or partially penniform; as, a semipenniform muscle.
Half or partly permanent.
Half transparent; imperfectly clear; semipellucid.
Partially impregnated with phlogiston.
A feather which has a plumelike web, with the shaft of an ordinary feather.
Somewhat precious; as, semiprecious stones or metals.
Half proof; evidence from the testimony of a single witness.
An aspect of the planets when distant from each other the half of a quadrant, or forty-five degrees, or one sign and a half.
An aspect of the planets when distant from each other half of the quintile, or thirty-six degrees.
Half hidden or half covered; said of the head of an insect when half covered by the shield of the thorax.
One of the incomplete rings of the upper part of the bronchial tubes of most birds. The semerings form an essential part of the syrinx, or musical organ, of singing birds.
One who is half savage.
Half Saxon; -- specifically applied to the language intermediate between Saxon and English, belonging to the period 1150-1250.
An aspect of the planets when they are distant from each other the twelfth part of a circle, or thirty degrees.
A half sound; a low tone.
A fasciole of a spatangoid sea urchin.
The tangent of half an arc.
One belonging to the Semitic race. Also used adjectively.
Having the characteristics of both a tertian and a quotidian intermittent.
Of or pertaining to Shem or his descendants; belonging to that division of the Caucasian race which includes the Arabs, Jews, and related races.
Half a tone; -- the name commonly applied to the smaller intervals of the diatonic scale.
The half of a transept; as, the north semitransept of a church.
Slightly clear; transmitting light in a slight degree.
Imperfect or partial transparency.
Half or imperfectly transparent.
The quality or state of being semivitrified.
A substance imperfectly vitrified.
Of or pertaining to a semivowel; half cocal; imperfectly sounding.
A sound intermediate between a vowel and a consonant, or partaking of the nature of both, as in the English w and y.
Coming, or made, or done, once every half week; as, a semiweekly newspaper; a semiweekly trip.
The fine, hard parts of wheat, rounded by the attrition of the millstones, -- used in cookery.
A genus of fleshy-leaved plants, of which the houseleek (Sempervivum tectorum) is the commonest species.
Of neverending duration; everlasting; endless; having beginning, but no end.
Without beginning or end; eternal.
Future duration without end; the relation or state of being sempiternal.
A Roman coin equivalent to one twenty-fourth part of a Roman pound.
A Japanese coin, worth about one half of a cent.
Of six; belonging to six; containing six.
The upper and less numerous branch of a legislature in various countries, as in France, in the United States, in most of the separate States of the United States, and in some Swiss cantons
Entitled to elect a senator, or by senators; as, the senatorial districts of a State.
The office or dignity of a senator.
To cause to go in any manner; to dispatch; to commission or direct to go; as, to send a messenger.
To pitch; as, the ship sends forward so violently as to endanger her masts.
Gum senegal. See under Gum.
A substance extracted from the rootstock of the Polygala Senega (Seneca root), and probably identical with polygalic acid.
The state of growing old; decay by time.
Growing old; decaying with the lapse of time.
Of or pertaining to old age; proceeding from, or characteristic of, old age; affected with the infirmities of old age; as, senile weakness.
More advanced than another in age; prior in age; elder; hence, more advanced in dignity, rank, or office; superior; as, senior member; senior counsel.
Belonging to the final year of the regular course in American colleges, or in professional schools.
One older in office, or whose entrance upon office was anterior to that of another; one prior in grade.
To exercise authority; to rule; to lord it.
The plants themselves, native to the East, but now cultivated largely in the south of Europe and in the West Indies.
